title: Mark Zuckerberg just gave Facebook employees all of Thanksgiving week off
text: The move is meant to reward employees for the work they've done during "unprecedented challenges."

title: Analysis: Two words describe the Senate's latest Big Tech hearing: Worthless and petty
text: In 1994, Congress dragged the CEOs of the nation's largest tobacco companies to Capitol Hill, where they testified — under oath — that cigarettes are not addictive, contrary to evidence otherwise. It was a watershed moment for the tobacco industry and marked the beginning of the end of Big Tobacco's dominance in America.

title: Here's how tech's most valuable companies have performed under Trump
text: Tech's five biggest companies all report earnings this week, giving investors one last look at results before next week's election.

title: Big Tech CEOs grilled on Capitol Hill on Section 230, hate speech, and censorship

title: Tech giants lost more than $270 billion in market value in the last two days

title: 4 Top Stock Trades for Thursday: GE, BA, FSLR, FB
text: Facebook, General Electric, Boeing and First Solar were our top stock trades for Thursday. That said, let's have a look at the charts.

title: Senators Accuse Big Tech CEOs of Abusing Their Power
text: Oct.28 -- The leaders of big U.S. technology companies came to testify about legislation that shaped the modern internet. They ended up being accused by senators of abusing their power over political speech six days before the election.

title: Why Facebook Stock Fell 5% on Wednesday
text: The social network was the target of the Senate Commerce Committee on Wednesday.

title: Opinion: Forget bias, the real danger is Big Tech's overwhelming control over speech
text: Less than a week before the US presidential election, the CEOs of Google, Facebook and Twitter appeared before the Senate Commerce Committee to testify about Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act — the 1996 law that limits platforms' liability for content posted by users and gives them latitude to moderate content as they see fit. The question at hand was whether Section 230 should be reformed to hold these tech companies accountable for the content on their platforms and for their moderation practices.

title: Republicans used a Senate hearing to criticize tech CEOs for fact-checking Trump's posts before the election (FB, GOOGL, TWTR)
text: The CEOs of Facebook, Google, and Twitter were subpoenaed to testify before Congress on Wednesday about Section 230, a foundational law of the internet that both Democrats and Republicans are angling to rewrite. But Section 230 itself barely came up at the hearing.

title: Congress vs. Facebook: Best moments in 16 minutes (supercut)
text: Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg faced questions from the Senate Commerce Committee on foreign election interference, political bias and fake news. title: Economic cost of new EU tech rules could top $100.5 billion, study says
text: The European Union's plan to rein in U.S. tech giants with new rules could cost the 27-country bloc as much as 85 billion euros ($100.5 billion) in economic growth, Brussels-based think tank ECIPE warned.

title: Sen Klobuchar, Zuckerberg clash over political advertisements on Facebook
text: Senator Amy Klobuchar, D-Minn., and Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg clash over political advertisements during the Big Tech hearings.

title: Tech stocks lead the market lower amid disappointing Microsoft outlook and congressional hearing with industry CEOs
text: US technology stocks cratered in Wednesday trades, leading the broader market lower amid congressional testimony on Section 230 from the CEOs of Twitter, Facebook, and Alphabet. Section 230 is a 1996 law that protects internet platforms from being held liable for content posted by its users.

title: Zuckerberg Says We Can't Stop Russia From Trying to Interfere in Elections
text: Oct.28 -- “We can't stop countries like Russia from trying to interfere in the election," Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg told a Senate panel. He says only the U.S. government can do that.

title: Facebook, Google and Twitter CEOs defend Section 230 to senators
text: The CEOs of Facebook, Google and Twitter will face lawmakers once again on Wednesday — this time to defend the legal liability shield that underpins their business models. For Facebook's Mark Zuckerberg and Google's Sundar Pichai, it will be their second time testifying before Congress this year, following July's antitrust hearing in the House.

title: Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg to Congress: Section 230 helped create the internet as we know it
text: The CEOs of Facebook, Google and Twitter return to Congress today to defend their legal liability shield to lawmakers keen to weaken it. Watch Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg's full opening testimony to the Senate Commerce Committee.

title: Facebook, Google and Twitter C.E.O.s return to Washington to defend their content moderation.
text: Facebook, Google and Twitter C.E.O.s return to Washington to defend their content moderation.

title: Facebook, Google, Twitter CEOs take heat in Senate over content
text: The scolding comes amid bipartisan criticism against Big Tech, a day before all four companies under regulatory scrutiny -- Alphabet Inc.'s Google, Facebook Inc., Apple Inc., and Amazon.com Inc. -- report earnings. So far, none have shown the financial effects of government scrutiny.

title: Explainer: What's in the U.S. law protecting internet companies - and can it be changed?
text: The chief executives of Twitter Inc, Facebook Inc and Alphabet Inc's Google defended a law protecting internet companies before a Senate panel on Wednesday as lawmakers seek ways to hold Big Tech accountable for how they moderate content on their platforms.

title: Facebook, Google and Twitter CEOs set to defend their legal shield to Congress
text: In their written testimonies, the CEOs warn of the potential negative impacts of repealing key portions of Section 230.

title: Big Tech's chief executives are becoming regulars on Capitol Hill.
text: It used to be unusual to see a top tech executive face tough questioning before lawmakers on Capitol Hill. But that has changed in the past few years. Now, the chief executives of Facebook, Google and Twitter are old hands at Congressional hearings.

title: Is a Surprise Coming for Facebook (FB) This Earnings Season?
text: Facebook (FB) is seeing favorable earnings estimate revision activity and has a positive Zacks Earnings ESP heading into earnings season.

title: Senate Big Tech hearing: What to expect from Zuck, Dorsey, Pichai's Section 230 defense
text: Today's hearing by the Senate Commerce Committee will examine whether Section 230 has ‘outlived its usefulness in today's digital age.' It's another day and another hearing about Big Tech on Capitol Hill.

title: CEOs of Facebook, Twitter and Google set to be grilled in Senate hearing
text: On Wednesday, the Senate Commerce Committee will question the CEOs of Facebook, Google and Twitter amid cries of conservative bias and threats to change a crucial law, known as Section 230, that protects the companies' ability to moderate content as they see fit.

title: Facebook, Twitter, Google CEOs will defend law protecting tech platforms before U.S. Senate panel
text: The chief executives of three large tech companies will defend a law protecting internet companies before a Senate panel on Wednesday - a topic that has split U.S. lawmakers on ways to hold Big Tech accountable for how they moderate content on their platforms.

title: Facebook, Google and Twitter CEOs to be questioned over anti-conservative bias
text: Facebook, Google and Twitter are going to be questioned by Republican senators on Wednesday over allegations the platforms are biased against conservatives.
